title: 114_s1008
content: Federal Data Center Consolidation. The Administrator for the Office of E-Government and Information Technology defines a data center as a space for data storage and management, with the authority to modify the definition as needed. Each year from fiscal year 2015 to 2019, agency heads must submit data center inventories and consolidation plans to the Administrator, as required by the Act. The agency must submit a technical roadmap and approach for infrastructure utilization, energy efficiency, cost savings, and efficiency. This includes performance benchmarks like Power Utilization Effectiveness and Energy Star-rated equipment. Additionally, a detailed timeline for data center consolidation and quantitative goals for reducing assets and improving energy efficiency must be included. The agency must provide a roadmap for infrastructure utilization, energy efficiency, and cost savings. This should include performance metrics for data center consolidation goals, energy utilization gains, and investment/cost savings calculations for 5 years. The agency must provide a roadmap for infrastructure utilization, energy efficiency, and cost savings, including initial costs for data center consolidation, life cycle cost savings, quantitative progress towards goals, and any additional information required by the Administrator. The agency must submit required information through existing reporting structures. Each year, the agency's head must certify compliance with the Act, and the Inspector General must release a public report within 6 months of the agency's report release. After the agency releases the first updated asset inventory in fiscal year 2015, the agency head must respond to the Inspector General's report evaluating the completeness of the inventory. Any incomplete inventory identified by the Inspector General must be completed by the time the agency submits the required inventory update for fiscal year 2016. The agencies listed in this paragraph are part of the asset inventory update process. The listed agencies are part of the asset inventory update process. The agencies include the Department of Transportation, Department of Treasury, Department of Veterans Affairs, Environmental Protection Agency, General Services Administration, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, National Science Foundation, Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Office of Personnel Management, Small Business Administration, Social Security Administration, and United States Agency for International Development. Each agency listed must implement consolidation plans directed by their chief information officer and provide annual updates to the Administrator on cost savings and efficiency improvements. The Administrator sets annual deadlines for agencies to submit information. The Administrator oversees the submission of agency consolidation plans, reviews their completeness, monitors implementation, and updates cost savings projections annually. The Administrator is responsible for developing and publishing a goal for cost savings through the Federal Data Center Consolidation Initiative within a 5-year period, with annual updates until the end of 2019. The Administrator will publish a report on the actual savings achieved through the Federal Data Center Consolidation Initiative compared to projected savings. The report will be submitted to Congress and include updates on agency progress in submitting comprehensive asset inventories. The report will include updates on agency progress in submitting comprehensive asset inventories and consolidation plans, as well as the implementation progress of each agency's consolidation plan upon request from relevant committees. The Comptroller General of the United States will annually publish a report on the quality, completeness, and progress of agency asset inventory and consolidation plans as required by relevant committees. The Comptroller General of the United States will annually report on agency asset inventory and consolidation plans, including cost savings, implementation improvements, and Congressional considerations for data center consolidation. The agency head must respond to the Comptroller General within 90 days with a detailed plan to address deficiencies in implementing the data center consolidation initiative. If an agency consistently lags in implementation, the head may need to explain the difficulties and propose changes. To address deficiencies in implementing data center consolidation, agencies must make structural or personnel changes as needed. Agencies implementing data center consolidation and cloud computing must adhere to cybersecurity standards outlined in Federal guidelines, including the Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program and guidance from the National Institute of Standards and Technology. The Director of National Intelligence has the authority to waive requirements for elements of the intelligence community regarding classified information. The Director of National Intelligence has the authority to waive requirements for elements of the intelligence community, with the Act being repealed on October 1, 2019.
